</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Upon his return to France in late August 1893, Gauguin began to prepare an exhibition of painted and sculpted works he had created during his two years in Tahiti. In November forty-one paintings and assorted wood sculptures on Tahitian themes, along with three Brittany-related paintings, were shown in Paris at Durand-Ruel. Only three paintings sold.

When the exhibition closed, the unsold works returned to Gauguin. As photographs of his Paris studio at 6, rue Vercingétorix (see fig. 57.1, fig. 57.2, and fig. 57.3), and eyewitness accounts confirm, Gauguin had painted the walls a bright chrome yellow. The studio also housed paintings and woodcarvings from Gauguin’s Tahitian sojourn that were not exhibited at Durand-Ruel. Thus, by simply looking around his studio, he could select motifs from the array of art displayed on the yellow walls, as well as stacked on the floor, creating a brilliantly colored environment that documented, as well as romanticized, his encounter with the South Seas. Serving as visual aids, the works allowed him to muse upon his adventures as he spun them for fellow artists and literati, made new and experimental work, and wrote and rewrote his travel account and created the accompanying prints using boxwood matrices.

The Noa Noa Suite was printed in two campaigns during Gauguin’s lifetime—one in 1893–94 by the artist himself and the other in 1894 in collaboration with his friend Louis Roy—and received one printing after his death. In 1921 Gauguin’s youngest son, Pola, supervised the publication of a portfolio of black-and-white impressions pulled from eight of the ten surviving boxwood matrices (see fig. 57.4) for the suite. Unlike the experimental, expressive, and often hard-to-read impressions made by Gauguin (see cat. 57.1) and the limited but often brighter palette of those printed by Roy (see cat. 57.2), Pola Gauguin’s meticulously inked and pulled prints record in a straightforward manner every detail and represent the prints’ final state. The analysis that follows of what the print depicts relies on a 1921 impression (cat. 57.3), which conveys all of the information that Gauguin inscribed and carved into the woodblock. Gauguin’s intentions for sequencing the plates in his proposed publication were never clear, which has prompted many theories. For the order of plates presented here, see “Veiled in a Cloud of Fragrance.”

While Gauguin evidently did not include his 1891 painting Upa upa (The Fire Dance) (fig. 57.5 [W 433]) in the Durand-Ruel exhibition, he decided to use it as the basis for the seventh image of the Noa Noa Suite, which he titled Mahna no varua ino (The Devil Speaks) (cat. 57.1, cat. 57.2, cat. 57.3). Simplified and reversed on account of the printing process, the print repeats Upa upa’s nocturnal composition almost exactly, except for eliminating details in the painting that suggest a deep recession into depth on the right. Absent from the print are three figures in the right middle ground, and several additional bonfires and tiny figures in the far distance.

In the print, eight seated figures—four at the left and four at the right—occupy the foreground, their forms defined by the flickering light cast by a blazing fire. On the left are two sets of figures. An amorous couple embraces tightly at the far left; the woman’s head tilts back at an angle that reveals her face and hair, which falls into the crook of her partner’s right arm. The other pair seems to be conversing or gossiping; one, facing forward, leans toward the other, whom we see from behind. Below these four figures, the artist inserted his monogram, PGo, and the wood-block print’s title. Above them close parallel lines most likely define the sky.

In the middle of the print’s composition, the diagonal trunk of a coconut palm (see fig. 57.6) extends from left to right, dividing foreground from background. Gauguin’s device of placing a diagonal tree trunk or branch in a scene to introduce drama and compositional complexity, as well as to create frames for various motifs and to flatten space, dates back most famously to his 1888 painting Vision of the Sermon (Jacob Wrestling with the Angel) (fig. 57.7 [W 245]).

Closest to the viewer are four figures in another conversational group. The two outer figures face forward, while the two in the middle, both of whom wear pleated hats, appear to stare into the intense fire, whose flames extend upward and whose sparks fan out (although the small diagonal lines could also indicate smoke). Preliminary notations related to the onlookers in the painting and print are found on pages of Gauguin’s circa 1892–93 Carnet de Tahiti (Tahitian Sketchbook) (fig. 57.8, fig. 57.9, and fig. 57.10) and in the abat-jour-shaped design pasted onto page 173 (fol. 191R) of his bound 1893–1901 manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti (fig. 57.11). The Carnet de Tahiti also contains a page with a summary drawing in graphite, showing a standing figure tending a fire with flickering flames and/or billowing smoke, which the artist annotated with notations on color and the like (fig. 57.12).

In the upper right of Mahna no varua ino are two dancers. Like the earliest European explorers of Polynesia, Gauguin was deeply interested in the region’s social and religious customs, including dances; an early engraving (fig. 57.13) shows performers wearing traditional bark-cloth costumes. By the time Gauguin went to Tahiti, Christian missionaries, who had arrived there nearly a century before, had either Europeanized native dances by making performers cover themselves with Western-style clothing or had suppressed certain dances entirely, not only to discourage indigenous religious practices but also to do away with what they saw as violent and/or overtly sexual, and therefore unacceptable, forms of behavior. Perhaps the most objectionable dance was the upa upa, a cathartic ritual dance involving erotic movements suggesting copulation. The Europeans did not succeed in eradicating the upa upa entirely; it was reenacted for foreigners (see fig. 57.14 and fig. 57.15), and perhaps done clandestinely at night, using bonfires for illumination, as Gauguin’s painting and print might indicate. The dancing pair—wearing native, not missionary costumes—demonstrate two central movements of the dance: performers bent their legs to create a diamond shape and moved their knees in and out rapidly (such as the figure at near the edge of the composition); they also lifted their arms and shook their hips from side to side with speed and fluidity (the dancer nearer to the tree trunk). Gauguin’s choice of a title for his woodcut depiction of the upa upa that refers to the devil perhaps indicates a level of satire on his part: It was not until missionaries took Christianity to Tahiti that the natives were made to think of this dance as unholy, an invitation to sin.

During his first sojourn in Polynesia, Gauguin often depicted dancers in sketches (see fig. 57.16 and fig. 57.17 [Rewald 41]) and paintings. In two 1892 canvases, Mata mua (In Olden Times) (fig. 57.18 [W 467]) and Arearea (Joyousness) (fig. 57.19 [W 468]), and a study for the latter (fig. 57.20), the artist visualized them dancing as a form of worship in the presence of an imagined, monumental statue of the moon goddess, Hina, in a setting that suggests the setting of his home in Mataeia. Arearea was displayed prominently in Gauguin’s studio on rue Vergingétorix (see fig. 57.3). Upa upa dancers appear again, but not in the presence of a statue of Hina, in the 1892 Women at the River Bank (fig. 57.21 [W 574]).

After his return to Paris, Gauguin reprised the motif of upa upa performers in a fan design (fig. 57.22) [W 469]), informed by Arearea. Dancers feature in three 1894 paintings: Mahana no atua (Day of the God) (fig. 57.23 [cat. 72]), Arearea no varua ino (Words of the Devil) (fig. 57.24 [W 514]), and Nave nave moe (Sweet Dreams) (fig. 57.25 [W 512]). An 1894 watercolor transfer monotype, Tahitian Landscape with Five Figures, which derives from Women at the River Bank, includes a group of dancers executing the upa upa in front of a grove of trees (fig. 57.26). A letter from Gauguin to an unnamed collector dated 1896 is illustrated with sketches (fig. 57.27) based on Arearea no varua ino, including that painting’s two dancers. Gauguin’s fondness for the motif of dancing figures may have been his way of bringing to life a vital tradition whose disappearance he lamented.  
Peter Zegers

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry2" id="curatorial_entry2">The title of this plate, inscribed in capital letters at the bottom left near Gauguin’s monogram, is generally translated as “The day of the evil spirit.” Mahna appears to be a hapax and thus can be explained as a misspelling of mahana, a word meaning “sun” or “day,” which Gauguin used in other titles, including that of his 1894 painting Mahana no atua (The Day of the God) (fig. 57.28 [cat. 72]). Vārua means “soul, spirit” and ‘ino “bad, evil,” but the latter can also be used ironically or as an intensifier. Thus, Hiriata Millaud suggested vārua‘ino might be translated as “pure,” “extreme,” or “total” spirit. Nonetheless, vārua ‘ino is employed as a compound word to designate a malevolent spirit or ghost. Robert Louis Stevenson defined “the Polynesian varua ino or aitu o le vao” as “the near kinsman of the Transylvanian vampire” in In the South Seas, his account of his 1888 and 1889 cruises. A vārua ‘ino features in the title of several other works by Gauguin, one of which, Parau na te varua ino (fig. 57.29 [W 458]), was shown in his 1893 exhibition at Durand-Ruel, Paris; the catalogue translated its title as “Paroles du Diable” (Words of the Devil). It must be added that the “superstitions” ascribed to Tahitians, which Gauguin tended to consider in the same non-judgmental way as he had those of the rural Bretons, can be understood as survivals of pre-Christian beliefs and their “devils” as dethroned deities. An 1821 report on the state of the evangelical missions in Oceania had noted with satisfaction that the local gods had “fallen into the greatest discredit” and that people no longer hesitated “to call them evil spirits.”

Mahna no varua ino is unequivocally a night scene. It is the darkest plate of the whole Noa Noa Suite, so that mahana, as “sun” or “day,” seems paradoxical. But Tepano Jaussen’s 1861 Tahitian-French dictionary also mentions a secondary meaning, “heat,” which would appear logical in connection with the fire depicted in the image, and “day” can be understood in the metaphorical sense of “moment.” In addition, Millaud argued that Gauguin may have employed mahna to pun on mana, “power.”

The composition is a simplified version of the painting Upa upa (The Fire Dance) (fig. 57.30 [W 433]; see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works), with a reduced number of figures and a less detailed background. The indeterminacy of the setting was clearly important to Gauguin, who increased this effect by various means when pulling his own impressions of the print (see fig. 57.31 [Kornfeld 19]). Beyond the fact that what we see is taking place out of doors and that a coconut tree extends obliquely across the middle of the space, nothing can be surmised about the place and circumstances. As was often the case, the artist wanted to convey an atmosphere rather than describe particulars, but here the mystery may also refer to a situation of clandestinity, since the ‘upa‘upa dance was actively repressed by the religious and civil authorities. In 1879 Julien Viaud (Pierre Loti) described the “indecent” and “frenetic” dance that the French governor had, in vain, tried to prohibit. The narrator of The Marriage of Loti joined a circle formed around female dancers in the moonlight, accompanied by his young Tahitian lover, Rarahu, who preferred to remain seated and yet became “another creature” as the ‘upa‘upa “woke deep in her uneducated soul feverish lust and savagery.” The performance could thus effect through the senses the kind of anamnesis, or return of what has been repressed, that Gauguin was striving for (see cat. 55, Commentary). We do not know to what extent the artist could rely on direct evidence for his evocation of the ‘upa‘upa, but commentators have rightly observed that he did not distinguish between the sacred and mundane dimensions of this “cathartic form of pagan devotion.” For Stephen Eisenman, Mahna no varua ino makes “a historical and political claim: that regardless of the present rule of police or church, the pleasures of love (note the embracing figures at far left), and the sanctity of ancient religion, will win out.”

In the painting, the faces and lower parts of the couple in a tight embrace at the right reflect the red of the fire, making explicit the connection between heat, dance, and sexual union. In Loti’s novel, the ‘upa‘upa spectacle “burned Rarahu’s blood,” and Gauguin’s various writings weave a network of metaphors between the volcano, the potter’s kiln, sex, and artistic creativity. The love-making couple must have been particularly important to him, since it reappears as the main motif of Te faruru (Here We Make Love) (fig. 57.32 [cat. 58.1]), another plate of the Noa Noa Suite. This is all the more striking since there are only ten plates. Upa upa was not included in the 1893 exhibition of Gauguin’s Tahitian works in Paris, and the subject matter does not refer explicitly to any passage in the Noa Noa text. In Te faruru, a supernatural face in profile looms above the male lover’s head, and Gauguin intimated this uncanny presence in some impressions of Mahna no varua ino (see cat. 57.1) by producing chance optical and textural effects with the help of wax.

The two seated figures placed just above the title seem to take the path indicated by the love-making couple, since one of them leans against the other. On the right side of the print and in the foreground sits a group of four figures, two of whom (on either side) show their faces, while the remaining ones are turned toward the fire. The mighty and sinuous trunk of the coconut palm passes above their heads and visually separates them—as well as the dancers—from the main part of the fire rising to the top of the plate. This repoussoir severs two spatial planes and dramatizes the tonal contrast of fire and night. But it is more than a compositional device and has been justly compared (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works) with the tree that separates Breton women from their vision in Gauguin’s Vision of the Sermon (Jacob Wrestling with the Angel) (fig. 57.33 [W 245]). Charles Stuckey proposed to connect the two dancing figures of Upa upa with these two wrestling figures, who indeed look like a four-legged animal. But equally important is the fact that, in both cases, the tree draws a line and mediates between spectators and spectacle, visionaries and vision.

Are there reasons to consider the bonfire of Upa upa and Mahna no varua ino as a “vision”? Its size is certainly impressive, and the painting expands it into a pool of liquid lava. In the print, it has a more self-contained outline, distinguished from the sparks and smoke that extend from it like wings, but is all the more distinctive as a form. Henri Dorra compared Upa upa with what he considered as a preparatory drawing for it (fig. 57.34), in which seated Tahitian spectators encircle an idol-like figure and a group of dancers. He thought he could recognize the idol “in the turbulence of the central flame” of the painting: “. . . two reddish lines hinting at a mouth and three bluish stains suggesting asymmetrical eyes and a nose. It is as if the flame were the embodiment of a seated deity endowed with a large face and a small body.” Dorra found the motif repeated in Mahna no varua ino, “albeit with less distinct anthropomorphic features,” and Elizabeth Prelinger described it as “a flame shaped like a hand.”

For Gauguin, suggestion was an artistic strategy and a mode of communication. He agreed with the Symbolist poet Stéphane Mallarmé’s estimation of its superiority over description (see “Veiled in a Cloud of Fragrance”), and these subjective responses do justice to this tenet. Fire—like the associated embers, smoke, and clouds—belongs moreover to the natural phenomena conducive to imaginative perception, and visions provoked by gazing at one have been described by countless authors from Philostratus to George Sand. Leonardo included fire on a list of objects that he believed stimulated the imagination and helped artists “invent” landscapes, figures, and scenes. Gauguin may have wished to reflect on this property and its effects, which are felt in the two spectators absorbed by the spectacle of the flames. He could even have been aware of divinatory uses of fire, since E. S. Craighill Handy later reported that, in Polynesia, “knowledge of future or distant events” came to the psychically gifted in dreams, in a trance state, or “through gazing into a reflecting liquid or into a sacred fire.”

The anthropomorphic aspects perceived by Dorra and Prelinger in Gauguin’s representations of the fire were at best intimations on his part and can be fundamentally disputed. Dorra’s intuition of a relation between the fire and a divine presence, however, is worth pursuing, all the more as the artist took great care in animating the fire of Mahna no varua ino by pressing the paper into the cavities of the wood block and printing the crests left by his gouge. Gauguin knew from reading Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout’s 1837 Voyages aux îles du Grand Océan that ancient Polynesians did not represent their higher deities in anthropomorphic form, and, although he chose to figure large statues of Hina based on images of deified ancestors (see cat. 53, Commentary, and cat. 58, Commentary), he took a keen interest in aniconic or abstract manifestations of the divine. In his compilation of excerpts from Moerenhout, the 1892/93 manuscript Ancien culte mahorie (Ancient Maori Religion), he illustrated the belt of red feathers (maro ‘ura) that was an “image of the godhead and of fire” (fig. 57.35), making its wearer “almost the equal of the gods,” as well as depicting the metamorphosis of the war god ‘Oro into “an immense column of fire” (fig. 57.36).

Taking into account the reversal produced by the printing process, the column of fire can be compared to the other light area in Mahna no varua ino, the unidentified shape at the left, which the impressions printed by Louis Roy emphasize either with the same color as the fire itself (see cat. 57.2) or with a different one (see fig. 57.37). Aniconism—the avoidance of mimetic imagery—is an important tendency in monotheistic religions, and an aniconic theophany features prominently in the Jewish Bible with the episode of the Burning Bush (Exodus 3:1–6), in which Jehovah calls to Moses from within a bush that burns with fire but is not consumed. This biblical scene challenges representation and has been rarely treated in art (see fig. 57.38), but Gauguin was certainly aware of it and may have had it in mind when lending a numinous quality to his bonfire.

Another potential image worth inquiring into was noted by Stephen Eisenman when he described the coconut palm bisecting the fire as “a great, phallic tree” leaning “at a suggestive angle.” This is not a suggestion that seems relevant for the tree in Vision of the Sermon, but in other works by Gauguin, such as the 1889 Landscape with Two Breton Women (fig. 57.39), a close look at the “anatomy” of a leaning tree makes it very plausible. In the case of Upa upa and Mahna no varua ino, an allusion to an aroused sexual organ would be logical in connection with the “obscene” quality of the dance, the excitement it generates, and the amorous activities unfolding on the other side of the tree. This sexual reading of the scene is in no way incompatible with the religious one, and the size of this botanic erection gives it a monumentality in proportion with that of the sacred fire. In his 1893 manuscript Cahier pour Aline (Notebook for Aline), begun at the end of his first stay in Tahiti, Gauguin advocated free love and wrote that the “sin” of giving one’s body “is amply redeemed by the most beautiful act in the world, creation, which is a divine act in that it is a continuation of the Creator’s work.”

Since the vārua ‘ino of the title is not explicitly represented in the print, as it is in Parau na te varua ino and in other works, one may conclude that it is (in) the fire. Impressions of the first and second states of Mahna no varua ino (see fig. 57.40 [Kornfeld 19]) show that the central part of the fire—Prelinger’s “hand-like flame”—was there from the start. In view of this beacon piercing the night, Millaud’s hypothesis of a conflation of mana (power) and mahana (day, sun, heat)—a verbal pun paralleling the visual ones in the image—appears justified. It is also clear that the fire possesses the value of a figure, and oddities of its printing suggest that it may have played a role in the emergence of one of Gauguin’s most puzzling creations, the androgynous, idol-like Oviri, which first took form on paper before being burned in the great fire of the kiln as a “ceramic sculpture” (fig. 57.41 [Gray 113]). The two impressions of the Oviri wood-block print that Gauguin pasted side-by-side onto cardboard and dedicated to Mallarmé (fig. 57.42) were printed on the verso of two Roy impressions of Mahna no varua ino, cropped in such a way that the fire motif appears on both, but head to tail (fig. 57.43). Seen in reverse, the fire displays a general resemblance of outline with that of the Oviri figure, whose head is rounded like the (strange) bottom of the fire and whose legs dissolve like the forking flames. The visual connection between Oviri and Mahna no varua ino is admittedly slight, but it gains support from the fact that a double-face link between the two prints is repeated in at least two other cases: an impression of Oviri (fig. 57.44) on the back of a cropped impression of Mahna no varua ino (fig. 57.45)—emphasizing in this case the “column of fire” and the love-making couple—and a double impression of Oviri (fig. 57.46) on the verso of a complete impression of Mahna no varua ino (fig. 57.47).

This coincidence may be explained by issues of timing and expediency, but it could also indicate that Gauguin used his own work as a divination device and that the flickering and dancing embodiment of a primeval force­­—both indigenous and universal—that he pursued in the bonfire of Upa upa and Mahna no varua ino found in the “cruel enigma” of Oviri a more iconic, but no less inchoate and changing, avatar.  
Dario Gamboni

There are only two references to the painting Upa upa dating from Gauguin’s lifetime: on page 2 (fol. 2R), no. 6, in a list of his paintings in his 1892–93 Carnet de Tahiti (Tahitian Sketchbook); and the sale catalogue Vente de tableaux et dessins par Paul Gauguin (Hôtel Drouot, Feb. 18, 1895), which lists Feux de joies (Fires of Joy) under no. 36. The title Gauguin carved into the boxwood matrix of the print very likely influenced the French and English titles assigned to the painting by other parties after his death, in 1903. See Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: The Paintings of the First Trip to Tahiti (Garland, 1977), no. 9, p. 312.

Gauguin did not copy the description and explanations given by Moerenhout about the maro ‘ura, and he transformed his source’s “image of the diety and of fire” (“image de la divinité et du feu”) into a “symbol” of the same, probably restricting the use of “image” to its iconic sense. Following this usage, the fire in Mahna no varua ino might be considered a symbol, rather than an image, of the vārua ‘ino.

The episode of the burning bush, in which “the angel of the Lord” first appears and from which the voice of God is heard, could also be brought to bear on the motif of a bush with the intimation of facial features present in several works by Gauguin, including his 1888 painting Arlésiennes (Mistral) (cat. 10); see Dario Gamboni, Paul Gauguin: The Mysterious Centre of Thought, trans.
